questions.text: In a case of head injury, which patient would not require an immediate CT scan?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) One episode of vomiting

 

A single, isolated vomiting episode after head injury in an otherwise neurologically stable patient is considered low-risk and does not mandate immediate CT. CT is reserved for multiple episodes of vomiting or when associated with other red-flag features such as altered mental status, seizures, or focal deficits. Clinical observation is sufficient in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Child with post-traumatic seizure: Any seizure following head trauma increases the risk of intracranial bleeding or cortical contusion. CT scan is mandatory to rule out parenchymal or extra-axial hematoma.

 

Option B. Biker with skull fracture suspicion: Suspected skull fractures, especially basilar or depressed, always warrant urgent CT to detect underlying hematoma or dural tears. Clinical suspicion alone is enough to justify scanning.

 

Option C. RTA victim with GCS 12: A GCS less than 13 is a red flag for moderate to severe traumatic brain injury. These patients are at high risk of intracranial hematoma or cerebral edema and require immediate CT.

 

Canadian CT Head Rule

 

Patients would require a CT scan if any of the high-risk (to identify lesions re-quiring neurosurgical intervention) or medium-risk (to identify any significant CT abnormality) criteria are present:

 

High-Risk Criteria

 

  • Failure of GCS to reach 15 within 2 hours of injury
  • Suspected open or depressed skull fracture
  • Any sign of basal skull fracture
  • Two or more episodes of vomiting
  • Age 65 years or over

 

Medium-Risk Criteria

 

  • Amnesia extending back more than 30 minutes before injury
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., pedestrian struck by vehicle, fall from more than 3 feet or down more than 5 stairs, ejection from vehicle during a collision

 

(Patients could have LOC, some amnesia, and disorientation, as well as a GCS as low as 13 initially; those under age 16 and with focal neurological deficits or anticoagulation/coagulopathy were not included.)

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient is brought into the casualty with maxillofacial trauma following a road traffic accident (RTA). He is unconscious with a GCS of 7/15 and his SpO2 is dropping with absent breath sounds on right side. JVP is raised. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricothyrodotomy

 

This patient has severe maxillofacial trauma, making conventional oral or nasal intubation impossible. With a GCS of 7, definitive airway protection is mandatory. Cricothyrotomy provides a rapid surgical airway when standard intubation is not feasible. It is lifesaving in emergency trauma airway management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bag and mask ventilation: Not adequate in maxillofacial trauma because airway obstruction is likely, and it does not secure a definitive airway in an unconscious patient with low GCS.

 

Option C. Needle thoracostomy: The patient does have features of tension pneumothorax (absent breath sounds, raised JVP, hypoxia), but the airway must be secured first. Oxygenation will not improve without a patent airway.

 

Option D. Nasotracheal intubation: Contraindicated in maxillofacial trauma as it can worsen airway compromise, cause bleeding, and risk intracranial passage if base of skull fracture exists.

choices.text: BRCA1 is located on the long arm of chromosome 17
BRCA2 carcinomas are Luminal A type
BRCA2 mutation is associated with male breast carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the BRCA genes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BRCA1 mutation causes well-differentiated cancer

 

This statement is incorrect. BRCA1-associated breast cancers are typically high-grade, poorly differentiated tumors. They are usually triple-negative (ER–, PR–, HER2–) and show aggressive clinical behavior. They are not well-differentiated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BRCA1 is located on the long arm of chromosome 17: Correct. The BRCA1 gene is mapped to chromosome 17q21 and is a tumor suppressor gene involved in DNA repair.

 

Option C. BRCA2 carcinomas are Luminal A type: Correct. BRCA2-associated breast cancers are more likely to be ER-positive and fall under the Luminal A molecular subtype, which has a better prognosis compared to BRCA1 tumors.

 

Option D. BRCA2 mutation is associated with male breast carcinoma: Correct. Male breast cancer is strongly linked with BRCA2 mutations, though BRCA1 mutations can rarely be involved.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to your OPD with severe nausea and recurrent bilious vomiting. Her symptoms initially began as postprandial epigastric pain and early satiety, but have progressed over the last two weeks. She works as an actress, and tells you that her symptoms only started when she "landed a role in a TV serial" and was inspired to lose 15kgs. on a "crash diet". On physical exam, her abdomen is tender and slightly distended with high-pitched bowel sounds. A laparotomy is performed, and it is observed that the angle between her superior mesenteric artery and her aorta is significantly decreased. Which of the following structures is most likely to be obstructed by the artery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transverse portion of the duodenum

 

This describes Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome (Wilkie’s syndrome), where rapid weight loss leads to loss of mesenteric fat pad, decreasing the angle between SMA and the aorta. This narrows the aortomesenteric space and compresses the third (transverse/horizontal) part of the duodenum, leading to bilious vomiting, abdominal pain, and gastric outlet obstruction–like symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascending portion of the duodenum: This is the fourth part, which ascends to the duodenojejunal flexure. It is not compressed between SMA and aorta.

 

Option B. Descending portion of the duodenum: This second part lies vertically along the right side of the vertebral column and receives the bile and pancreatic ducts; it is not in the path of SMA compression.

 

Option C. Duodenal bulb: The first part (duodenal bulb) lies anterior to the portal triad and is commonly affected in peptic ulcer disease, but not compressed by SMA.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with a gradually enlarging neck mass over the past 2 months. Neck ultrasonography confirms a hypoechoic nodule with microcalcifications. Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy shows spindle-shaped cells in eosinophilic amorphous background. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Activation of RET

 

This patient most likely has medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), as suggested by FNA findings of spindle-shaped cells within an amyloid-rich stroma (derived from altered calcitonin). MTC arises from parafollicular C-cells and is strongly associated with germline mutations in the RET proto-oncogene (seen in MEN 2A and MEN 2B syndromes). Identification of RET mutation is crucial as it guides prophylactic thyroidectomy in affected families.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BRAF gene mutation: This is associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC), especially the tall-cell variant, and is linked to poor prognosis. It does not cause spindle cells with amyloid background.

 

Option C. Inactivation of p53: Seen in anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, an aggressive tumor of older patients, often with rapidly enlarging neck mass and invasion. Histology shows pleomorphic giant and spindle cells but without amyloid.

 

Option D. Overexpression of PTC gene: Rearrangements of RET/PTC oncogene are classically linked to papillary thyroid carcinoma, especially in radiation-induced cases, not medullary carcinoma.

choices.text: Stool PCR testing for Clostridioides difficile

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a 5-day history of left lower abdominal pain, nausea, and poor appetite. Although she has a history of chronic constipation, she has been having 2–3 loose, nonbloody bowel movements daily. History is notable for hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy 15 years ago.  Rectal and pelvic examinations elicit exquisite left-sided tenderness. Stool testing for occult blood is negative. Laboratory results include a white blood cell count of 16,500/mm³. Which of the following is the best next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CT scan of the abdomen

 

This patient has acute diverticulitis, suggested by left lower quadrant pain, leukocytosis, tenderness, and altered bowel habits. CT abdomen with contrast is the diagnostic test of choice, as it can identify inflamed diverticula, pericolic fat stranding, abscesses, or perforation. Endoscopic evaluation is avoided in the acute setting because of the risk of perforation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flexible sigmoidoscopy: Contraindicated in acute diverticulitis as insufflation can precipitate perforation. Colonoscopy is performed only after recovery to exclude malignancy or inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Option C. Stool culture: Useful in bacterial gastroenteritis, but this patient has no fever, bloody diarrhea, or infectious exposure history. Localized tenderness with leukocytosis is more consistent with diverticulitis.

 

Option D. Stool PCR testing for C. difficile: Indicated in patients with recent antibiotic use and profuse watery diarrhea. This patient has localized left-sided pain with systemic inflammation, not generalized diarrhea.

choices.text: Failure of fusion of the maxillary and mandibular processes
Failure of fusion of the maxillary and medial nasal processes
Failure of fusion of the lateral palatine processes

questions.text: Which of the following is the embryologic explanation for the malformation shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Failure of fusion of the maxillary and medial nasal processes

 

This embryological defect leads to the classic presentation of cleft lip, as the maxillary process fails to join with the medial nasal process during facial development.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Expansion of the foramen cecum: Relates to the development of the thyroid gland, not cleft lip or palate.
 

Option B. Failure of fusion of the maxillary and mandibular processes: Would affect lower facial formation, not typically associated with cleft lip.
 

Option D. Failure of fusion of the lateral palatine processes: Results in cleft palate, not cleft lip.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency with abdominal pain and an episode of binge drinking, in shock with a BP of 70/50 mm Hg and HR of 115/min. The oxygen saturation of the patient is 70 mm Hg. The serum creatinine level was 2.4 mg/dL. What is the likely diagnosis based on the CT image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Necrotising Acute pancreatitis

 

The CT scan shows areas of non-enhancement within the pancreas, indicating pancreatic necrosis. This finding, along with the clinical scenario of shock, severe abdominal pain, renal dysfunction (high creatinine), and history of alcohol binge, supports the diagnosis of necrotising acute pancreatitis—a life-threatening complication requiring intensive care.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Liver abscess: Presents as a rim-enhancing, localized hepatic lesion, not diffuse pancreatic-necrosis.

 

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: Demonstrates free gas under the diaphragm or in the peritoneal cavity, often due to perforation, not focal pancreatic changes.

 

 

Option D. Interstitial acute pancreatitis: Shows uniform pancreatic swelling and peripancreatic inflammation without areas of necrosis.

questions.text: All of the following are minimum standards for monitoring of a patient in shock except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Base deficit

 

Base deficit is an advanced laboratory marker of metabolic acidosis and tissue hypoperfusion, but it is not considered a minimum standard parameter for routine monitoring at the bedside for patients in shock.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. ECG: Essential for cardiac monitoring and rhythm assessment in shock.
 

Option B. Pulse oximetry: Mandatory for continuous monitoring of oxygen saturation in critically ill patients.
 

Option C. Urine output: Key indicator of end-organ perfusion and response to treatment, monitored via catheter.

 

ECG, pulse oximetry, and urine output are universally standard for shock monitoring; base deficit is not

questions.text: Identify the likely pathology from the thyroid scan pattern shown in the figure:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plummer disease

 

The thyroid scan shows a single area of intensely increased uptake (hot nodule) with suppression of the surrounding normal thyroid tissue. This “hot nodule” pattern is characteristic of Plummer disease (toxic adenoma), a type of hyperfunctioning thyroid adenoma.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Hypersecreting adenoma: Also presents as a hot nodule, but the specific terminology for a toxic adenoma causing thyrotoxicosis is Plummer disease. It carries a risk of 4% for maliganant conversion
 

Option B. Cold nodule: Appears as a region of decreased uptake (non-functioning area), not increased uptake. It carries a risk of 20% for maliganant conversion
 

Option C. Grave’s disease: Diffuse, homogeneous increased uptake throughout the entire thyroid gland, not a solitary hot nodule.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office due to pain, redness, and swelling in his right arm. The patient was recently diagnosed with unresectable lung cancer. He received the first cycle of chemotherapy 2 weeks ago through a right-sided peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC). Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 14/min. Oxygen saturation is normal. Examination shows right arm swelling and mild erythema. Capillary refill is normal. No discharge is seen around the PICC line. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duplex ultrasonography

 

This patient most likely has an upper extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to his PICC line, malignancy, and arm swelling with erythema. Duplex ultrasound is the diagnostic test of choice to confirm venous thrombosis. Early diagnosis is essential, as catheter-related thrombosis carries risks of pulmonary embolism and post-thrombotic syndrome. Image below shows Right PICC and thrombus in respectively

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest MRI: Not indicated as the first test. MRI is not required for suspected catheter-related thrombosis and would not provide immediate diagnostic confirmation compared to duplex ultrasound.

 

Option C. Empiric antibiotics: Indicated for catheter-related infection (fever, purulent discharge, systemic toxicity), but this patient is afebrile with no local discharge or systemic signs of infection.

 

Option D. Warm compresses and NSAIDs: These may provide symptomatic relief in superficial thrombophlebitis, but this patient has risk factors and clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis, which requires urgent confirmation and anticoagulation.

questions.text: All are components of MELD 3.0 score, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Platelet count

 

Platelet count is not a component of the MELD 3.0 score. Thrombocytopenia is often seen in cirrhosis due to splenic sequestration and portal hypertension, but it is not included in the MELD-based prognostic scoring system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. INR: Included in MELD, as it reflects hepatic synthetic function and degree of coagulopathy, both of which worsen with advanced liver disease.

 

Option B. Female sex: MELD 3.0 adjusted for female sex, since women were found to have higher waitlist mortality compared to men at the same MELD score.

 

Option D. Creatinine: A major component of MELD, reflecting renal dysfunction, which is strongly associated with poor prognosis in cirrhotic patients.

questions.text: A man presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident with complaints of chest pain and difficulty breathing. An X-ray was taken and is displayed below. Based on the findings, which type of breathing pattern is most likely observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paradoxical respiration

 

The chest X-ray shows multiple rib fractures on one side suggestive of a flail chest, which can cause paradoxical movement of the chest wall segment during respiration (inward movement during inspiration and outward during expiration).

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Cheyne-Stokes respiration: Characterized by cyclic crescendo-decrescendo breathing with apnea, usually in neurological or cardiac conditions, not trauma.
 

Option C. Biot's respiration: Irregular breathing with periods of apnea, seen in brainstem injury.
 

Option D. Kussmaul respiration: Deep and rapid breaths, commonly in metabolic acidosis such as diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being struck by a car while he was crossing the street one hour ago. He did not lose consciousness. He has pain in his right arm, forehead, and pelvis. He also has an urge to urinate but has been unable to do so since the accident. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/82 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time.  Musculoskeletal examination shows tenderness and ecchymosis over the right distal forearm with intact pulses, sensation, and capillary refill. Abdominal examination shows suprapubic tenderness. A scant amount of blood is present at the urethral meatus. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a fracture of both ipsilateral pubic rami. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retrograde urethrography

 

The presence of blood at the urethral meatus, suprapubic tenderness, and pelvic fracture raise suspicion of urethral injury. Retrograde urethrography is the appropriate diagnostic test to evaluate for urethral disruption before any attempt at catheterization.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. CT cystography: Used to assess bladder injuries, typically after confirmed urethral injury or if indicated by hematuria and pelvic trauma.
 

Option C. Foley catheterization: Contraindicated initially if urethral injury is suspected until injury is ruled out.
 

Option D. Intravenous pyelography: Used for upper urinary tract imaging, not for initial urethral injury assessment.

questions.text: What is the angle between the telescope and a working instrument in a laparoscopy defined as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azimuth angle 

 

  • The azimuth angle is the angle formed between the axis of the laparoscope (telescope) and the axis of a working instrument.
  • Ideal range: 30°–60°, which allows proper triangulation and minimizes clashing of instruments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manipulation angle: This is the angle subtended at the target tissue by two working instruments. Ideally 60°–75°, it determines the surgeon’s precision and ergonomics.

 

Option C. Elevation angle: The angle between the working instrument and the horizontal plane, important for depth perception and movement control.

 

Option D. Veress angle: No such angle is defined; the Veress needle is used for creating pneumoperitoneum, not for intraoperative ergonomic measurements.

choices.text: Medications currently taken by the patient
Names of team members and associated roles

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease resulting in cirrhosis comes to the emergency department due to worsening abdominal distension, pain, fatigue, and dyspnea for the past 3 days. Medical history includes gastrointestinal reflux disease and hypertension. The abdomen is distended with shifting dullness and tenderness. There is 2+ pedal edema. Laboratory results show thrombocytopenia and mildly elevated PT.  Prompt diagnostic paracentesis is recommended, and risks and benefits of the procedure are discussed with the patient. The patient provides informed consent, and the medical team makes appropriate preparations for the procedure. Immediately prior to inserting the paracentesis needle, a time-out is called. Which of the following information is most essential to include during the time-out?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type of procedure being performed

 

  • A "time-out" is part of the Universal Protocol for Preventing Wrong Site, Wrong Procedure, and Wrong Person Surgery.
  • Immediately before starting, the team must verify: correct patient, correct procedure, correct site.
  • Among the given choices, the type of procedure being performed is the essential element to prevent catastrophic errors like performing the wrong intervention.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Indication for performing the procedure: While important for clinical reasoning and documentation, it is not part of the core elements of the procedural safety time-out.

 

Option B. Medications currently taken by the patient: Relevant for peri-procedural safety (e.g., anticoagulants), but medication review is completed before consent and preparation, not during the final time-out.

 

Option C. Names of team members and associated roles: Useful in complex surgeries for communication and accountability, but the essential universal protocol emphasizes correct patient, procedure, and site above all else.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to nausea, vomiting, and increasing abdominal pain over the last 3 hours. Four weeks ago he was discharged from the hospital following an inpatient admission for acute myocardial infarction. His other medical problems include type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and peptic ulcer disease. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min and irregular, and respirations are 22/min. The patient appears to be in severe distress due to pain. There is diffuse abdominal tenderness, but it is more pronounced over the lower right quadrant. 

Liver function studies:
Amylase: 275 U/L
Lipase: 80 U/L (normal, 0-160 U/L)

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bowel ischemia

 

  • This patient with recent myocardial infarction and now presenting with acute severe abdominal pain, irregular pulse (likely atrial fibrillation), nausea, vomiting, and tenderness is highly suggestive of acute mesenteric ischemia due to embolic occlusion of the superior mesenteric artery.
  • Importantly, serum amylase can be moderately elevated in bowel ischemia, leading to diagnostic confusion with pancreatitis, but lipase is not significantly elevated.
  • The “pain out of proportion to physical findings” is a hallmark early clue in bowel ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute appendicitis: Typically begins with periumbilical pain migrating to the right lower quadrant with fever and leukocytosis, not diffuse severe pain with cardiovascular risk factors.

 

Option B. Acute pancreatitis: Would present with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, often with elevated amylase AND lipase (lipase being more specific). Here, lipase is normal, making pancreatitis less likely.

 

Option D. Diabetic ketoacidosis: Commonly presents with polyuria, polydipsia, Kussmaul respirations, fruity odor on breath, and metabolic acidosis. Abdominal pain can occur, but acute cardiovascular history and focal abdominal tenderness point away from DKA.

questions.text: As per the ANDI classification of benign breast disorders, all of the following would be considered under disorders of early reproductive years, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipple eversion 

 

  • The ANDI classification groups benign breast disorders based on life stages:
    • Early reproductive years → Fibroadenoma, adolescent hypertrophy, nipple inversion, juvenile hypertrophy.
    • Late reproductive years → Fibrocystic changes, mastalgia, duct ectasia.
    • Perimenopausal & postmenopausal → Lobular involution, sclerosing adenosis, carcinoma risk changes.
  • Nipple eversion is a normal variant and not a pathological disorder; hence it is not part of ANDI classification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adolescent hypertrophy: Occurs in early reproductive years due to hormonal hypersensitivity; causes massive, rapid breast enlargement in adolescence.

 

Option C. Fibroadenoma: Most common benign breast tumor of young women; estrogen-dependent, seen in late teens and early 20s.

 

Option D. Nipple inversion: May be congenital or develop in early reproductive years due to ductal shortening; included under ANDI disorders.

 

Classification of ANDI:

choices.text: Insert IV cannula and start IV fluids

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with sudden onset breathlessness and a sharp pain in his left chest after a road traffic accident. His BP is 85/69mm Hg and HR is 110bpm. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Needle thoracostomy

 

The chest X-ray shows evidence of tension pneumothorax, such as a collapsed left lung and shift of mediastinal structures to the right. In the clinical context of shock and respiratory distress, immediate needle thoracostomy is life-saving and should be performed without delay.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. eFAST: Used for trauma assessment, but this patient needs urgent decompression of the tension pneumothorax first.
 

Option B. Insert IV cannula and start IV fluids: Useful in shock but does not address the cause of respiratory compromise in tension pneumothorax.
 

Option D. Intubate the patient: Not indicated prior to relieving tension pneumothorax, as airway management alone will not resolve lung collapse.

questions.text: A young female presents with pain in lower abdomen and vomiting in the ER. Clinical examination reveals a swelling, lateral and below the pubic tubercle. X-ray is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strangulated femoral hernia

 

The clinical scenario and X-ray findings indicate a femoral hernia, which typically presents as a swelling below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. Associated pain, vomiting, and features of intestinal obstruction point toward strangulation, requiring urgent intervention.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Adhesions: Common cause of intestinal obstruction, but would not present as a groin swelling below the pubic tubercle.
 

Option B. Strangulated inguinal hernia: Swelling would be above and medial to the pubic tubercle, differing from the femoral hernia location.
 

Option D. Direct hernia: Occurs due to weakness in the abdominal wall, presenting as a swelling above the pubic tubercle, not below and lateral.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

 

  1. Liposarcoma is the most common retroperitoneal tumor.
  2. M3 midline hernia refers to epigastric hernia 
  3. A mesenteric cyst shows mobility perpendicular to line of mesenteric attachment.
  4. Colon cancer risk can be decreased by metformin
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. Liposarcoma is the most common retroperitoneal tumor: Correct. Liposarcoma is the most frequent primary malignant retroperitoneal soft tissue tumor, followed by leiomyosarcoma.

 

Statement 3. A mesenteric cyst shows mobility perpendicular to line of mesenteric attachment: Correct. Mesenteric cysts move freely at right angles to the root of mesentery, but not parallel to it (due to mesenteric tethering).

 

Statement 4. Colon cancer risk can be decreased by metformin: Correct. Several studies show that metformin reduces colon cancer risk in diabetics by improving insulin sensitivity and reducing hyperinsulinemia (which is a growth-promoting factor for colonic epithelium).

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. M3 midline hernia refers to epigastric hernia: Incorrect. According to the European Hernia Society classification, M3 = umbilical hernia. Epigastric hernia corresponds to M2.

questions.text: Calculate for Burn Surface Area (BSA) for a patient with burn involving the anterior torso, upper right arm and circumferential right thigh:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31.5% 

 

Calculation (adult, Rule of Nines / simple regional breakdown used):

 

  • Anterior torso = 18% (half of the trunk = 18%).
  • Upper right arm = 4.5% (whole arm = 9%, so upper arm ≈ half of the arm = 4.5%).
  • Circumferential right thigh = 9% (thigh ≈ half of the entire lower limb; whole lower limb = 18%, so thigh ≈ 9%).

 

Total = 18 + 4.5 + 9 = 31.5%.

 

Calculation of BSA in burns based on RULE OF NINES:

questions.text: A  59-year-old man comes to the OP for a postoperative follow-up. He underwent a partial gastrectomy for a perforated peptic ulcer 3 weeks ago. For the last 10 days, he has had intermittent abdominal cramps and diarrhea. Symptoms begin 25-30 minutes after eating and are associated with nausea, weakness, palpitations, light-headedness, and diaphoresis. On examination, the abdomen is soft and nontender with normal bowel sounds. The surgical wound is healing well without erythema or discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dietary modification

 

This patient has early dumping syndrome, a complication after gastrectomy or gastric bypass.

 

  • Pathophysiology: Rapid emptying of hyperosmolar gastric contents into the small intestine → fluid shifts into the lumen → intestinal distension and autonomic response.
  • Symptoms: Postprandial abdominal cramps, diarrhea, nausea, weakness, palpitations, diaphoresis, light-headedness.
  • First-line management is dietary modification: small, frequent meals, avoidance of simple carbohydrates, increased protein and fiber, and separation of solids/liquids during meals.
  • Medications (e.g., octreotide) are reserved for severe/refractory cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopy: Useful if there are concerns of anastomotic leak, ulcer recurrence, or obstruction, but not indicated here because symptoms are classic for dumping syndrome and exam is normal.

 

Option C. Trial of octreotide: A somatostatin analog that slows gastric emptying and inhibits release of GI hormones; used when dietary modification fails, not as first-line.

 

Option D. Upper gastrointestinal contrast study: Ordered if mechanical obstruction, anastomotic stricture, or leak is suspected; not needed in this classic case.

choices.text: 3 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line
7 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line
3 cm below the right costal margin at the mid-axillary line
7 cm below the right costal margin at the mid-clavicular line

questions.text: Palmer's point is the point where you would insert the Veress needle. Identify it:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line

 

Palmer's point is located 3 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line. This is the site where the Veress needle is inserted (typically when the umbilical site is contraindicated). It is preferred because it offers a relatively safe upper left quadrant site free of major vascular and visceral structures. The other options either are incorrectly placed or pose higher risk, hence are not standard sites for Veress needle insertion.


Various other points used for Veeres needle insertion are pictured below :

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Triple H therapy used in the management of vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

Triple H therapy is a classic supportive treatment for cerebral vasospasm after subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

It consists of:

 

  1. Hypertension → increases cerebral perfusion pressure.
  2. Hypervolemia → expands intravascular volume, maintaining cerebral blood flow.
  3. Hemodilution → lowers blood viscosity, improving flow through narrowed vessels.

 

Hypothermia is not part of Triple H; it has experimental neuroprotective roles but is not included in vasospasm management protocol.

questions.text: Reynold’s pentad includes all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hematemesis 

 

Reynold’s pentad is seen in severe acute suppurative cholangitis and includes:

 

  1. Charcot’s triad – fever, jaundice, right upper quadrant pain
  2. PENTAD: TRIAD + Hypotension (shock) + Altered mental status (confusion)

 

Hematemesis is not a feature; it suggests upper gastrointestinal bleeding (e.g., varices, peptic ulcer).

questions.text: During the secondary survey of a trauma patient, an AMPLE history is taken to gather critical information. Which of the following is not a part of the AMPLE history?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lucid interval

 

  • AMPLE history is a rapid mnemonic used during trauma secondary survey:
    • A → Allergies
    • M → Medications currently taken
    • P → Past medical history / Pregnancy
    • L → Last meal
    • E → Events/environment related to the injury
  • Lucid interval is a clinical feature of epidural hematoma, not part of AMPLE history.

questions.text: A trauma patient suffered a renal laceration with urine extravasation. He was managed conservatively. However, after a few days, he presented with a urinoma. The next best management for this patient would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureteral stenting

 

  • Urinoma is a collection of urine in the retroperitoneum due to urine leak after renal trauma.
  • First-line management in a hemodynamically stable patient with urinary extravasation is internal urinary diversion via ureteral stent placement.
  • This allows urine to bypass the site of injury, promotes healing, and prevents infection or further collection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Surgical repair and exploration: Surgical repair is reserved for severe injuries with persistent leak despite stenting or associated vascular/collecting system injury.

 

Option D. Pigtail drainage of collection: Percutaneous drainage (pigtail) is usually adjunctive if the urinoma is infected. 

 

Option C. Observation: Observation alone is insufficient if the urinoma is enlarging or symptomatic.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with acute onset fever and dysuria. Urine examination revealed plenty of leukocytes with glycosuria. A CT scan of the abdomen was done. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Emphysematous pyelonephritis

 

Option B:

 

Given CT scan shows an enlarged kidney with areas of necrosis and mottled areas of gas collection. This is suggestive of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

 

Emphysematous Pyelonephritis (Correct Diagnosis):

 

  • It is an acute, severe infection of the renal parenchyma and surrounding tissues that results in the presence of gas within the renal parenchyma, collecting system, or perinephric tissue.
  • It is more common in diabetic patients and those with urinary obstruction.
  • The CT scan shows mottled gas collections within the renal tissue, characteristic of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute Pyelonephritis:

 

  • This is a bacterial infection causing inflammation of the kidney and renal pelvis.
  • The CT scan might show areas of striated nephrogram or wedge-shaped areas of poor enhancement, but without the presence of gas within the renal parenchyma, which is seen in this case.

 

Option C. Perinephric Abscess:

 

  • It involves the accumulation of pus around the outside of the kidney but within the Gerota fascia.
  • CT findings typically include a fluid collection with an enhancing rim, but not the extensive gas formation within the kidney itself.

 

Option D. Renal Abscess:

 

  • This refers to a localized collection of pus within the renal parenchyma.
  • A CT scan may show a round or oval fluid collection with an enhancing rim within the renal parenchyma, but, again, not typically associated with the extensive gas pattern observed in emphysematous pyelonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT scan showing an enlarged kidney with areas of necrosis and mottled areas of gas collection is suggestive of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in the right side of his face. Upon examination, the physician noted swelling in the submandibular gland. The patient also reported that his symptoms worsened when he ate food, and he had lost his appetite due to the discomfort. USG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sialolithiasis

 

The ultrasound image shows a hyperechoic structure with posterior acoustic shadowing within the right submandibular duct, indicating a salivary stone (sialolith). This finding, combined with symptoms of pain and swelling that worsen during meals, is classic for sialolithiasis.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Pleomorphic adenoma: Usually presents as a well-defined, hypoechoic, solid mass in the gland, not a calcified lesion in the duct.
 

Option C. Osteoma of floor of mouth: Rare, and would be seen as a dense bony structure, not within the submandibular duct.
 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Appears as enlarged, rounded lymph nodes in the cervical chain, unrelated to ductal stones.

questions.text: A 7 month old baby boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to “empty scrotum”. On examination, hemiscrotum on right side is not developed and testis is not palpable in the inguinal region. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diagnostic laparoscopy

 

In a 7-month-old infant with non-palpable undescended testis and absent hemiscrotum, diagnostic laparoscopy is the next step. It helps to locate an intra-abdominal or blind-ending testis and plan further management.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. HCG test dose: Used for cryptorchidism but usually at an older age and when testis is palpable.
 

Option C. Reassurance: Not appropriate without confirming the location of the testis in non-palpable cases.
 

Option D. Inguinal exploration: Considered if testis is palpable in the inguinal canal but not detected on laparoscopy.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the MRCP image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Choledochal cyst

 

The MRCP image you shared shows a large, smooth, cystic dilatation of the common bile duct with communication to the biliary tree.

 

  • Characterized by congenital cystic dilatation of the extrahepatic (± intrahepatic) bile ducts.
  • MRCP: smooth, saccular or fusiform cystic dilatation of CBD → exactly as seen here.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Biliary ascariasis: Would show a linear filling defect (worm) inside the bile duct, not a cystic dilatation.

 

 

Option C. Caroli disease: Involves intrahepatic bile duct dilatation with “central dot sign.” This image shows extrahepatic dilatation, not typical of Caroli.

 

 

Option D. Choledocholithiasis: Would show a filling defect (stone) inside CBD, not a large smooth cystic dilatation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to the OPD with a scald injury on his arm. The lesion was pink, oozing, and painful to moving air and touch. Which of the following would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paraffin gauze dressing

 

  • This patient has a superficial partial-thickness burn, as indicated by pink, moist, oozing skin and pain on touch/air movement.
  • Management:
    • Non-adherent dressings such as paraffin gauze or hydrocolloid dressings are ideal to maintain a moist environment, prevent infection, and allow pain-free dressing changes.
    • Healing usually occurs in 7–14 days without grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silver sulphadiazine cream dressing: Historically used, but it forms a pseudoeschar and adheres to the wound, making dressing changes painful. Not ideal for superficial partial-thickness burns.

 

Option B. Excision and grafting: Reserved for deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns, typically when spontaneous healing is unlikely (>3 weeks) or in large areas.

 

Option D. Collagen dressing: Useful in full thickness burns, chronic wounds, or donor sites

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with a thyroid nodule. Serum TSH is normal. Ultrasound of her thyroid reveals a 1.5-cm hypoechoic nodule in the right thyroid lobe with irregular margins, internal microcalcifications, and internal vascularity. FNAC is performed which is reported as Thy3 Bethesda grade. Which of the following is the next most appropriate step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemi-thyroidectomy 

 

Thy3 / Bethesda III corresponds to follicular lesion of undetermined significance or follicular neoplasm, with a 10–30% risk of malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat FNAC: May be considered in some Thy3 nodules, but suspicious ultrasound features and patient preference usually favor diagnostic surgery.

 

Option B. MRI of the neck: Not indicated for evaluation of thyroid nodules; it is reserved for large, invasive, or retrosternal masses or for staging.

 

Option D. RAIU scan: Useful only if TSH is suppressed to differentiate “hot” vs “cold” nodules; in euthyroid patients, a cold nodule on RAIU may indicate higher malignancy risk, but ultrasound + FNAC already guides management here.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman complains of fatigue, weight gain, and increased sensitivity to cold. On physical examination, she has noticeable swelling in her neck. The histological image is shown below. Additionally, an ultrasound examination shows that her thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and has an uneven texture. Which of the following conditions is most likely the cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hashimoto’s thyroiditis 

 

The histological image reveals lymphoid follicles with germinal centers and abundant lymphocytic infiltration within the thyroid parenchyma. Clinically, the patient displays symptoms of hypothyroidism, a diffusely enlarged and heterogeneous thyroid gland, and the classical histopathology of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTC (Medullary thyroid carcinoma): Characterized by spindle-shaped or polygonal cells, amyloid stroma, and not prominent lymphoid infiltration.


Option B. de-Quervian thyroiditis: Presents with granulomatous inflammation and giant cells, not lymphoid follicles.

 

 

Option C. Grave's disease: Shows tall columnar follicular cells, scalloped colloid, and increased vascularity, not lymphocytic infiltration and germinal centers.

questions.text: A surgeon returns the entire hernial sac into the abdominal cavity of a patient with an inguinal hernia without reducing its contents. What is this known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduction en masse

 

Reduction en masse occurs when a hernial sac is pushed back into the preperitoneal space without freeing the entrapped contents, so the loop of bowel remains incarcerated or strangulated inside the sac.

 

Clinically, the external bulge disappears, giving a false impression of successful reduction, but the patient may still develop bowel obstruction or strangulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maydl's hernia: Characterized by a W-shaped loop of bowel, where the central loop inside the sac may become strangulated while the outer loops appear viable.

 

 

 

Option C. Sliding hernia: Occurs when a retroperitoneal organ (colon, bladder, cecum) forms part of the hernial sac wall, common in elderly men.

 

 

Option D. Incarcerated hernia: A hernia whose contents cannot be reduced, leading to obstruction. Unlike reduction en masse, the sac is not forcibly pushed back into the abdomen. If left untreated, it might lead to Strangulation.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presented with recurrent bilious vomiting. An X-ray erect abdomen is shown below. What is the next best step in managing this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastrograffin follow-through 

 

The abdominal X-ray in a neonate with recurrent bilious vomiting shows multiple air-fluid levels and a double bubble sign, suggestive of duodenal obstruction or malrotation with volvulus. The next best step is a contrast (Gastrograffin) follow-through study to delineate the anatomy and confirm the level and cause of obstruction before surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Upper GI endoscopy: Not indicated acutely for initial evaluation of neonatal obstruction.

 

Option C. Air enema: Used for intussusception, not for duodenal or proximal small bowel obstruction in neonates.

 

Option D. Explorative laparotomy: Reserved for cases with confirmed diagnosis or evidence of bowel compromise; not the immediate next investigation.

choices.text: Delayed cholecystectomy prior to the hospital discharge
Elective cholecystectomy 2 weeks after complete recovery

questions.text: 75-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to fever, chills, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days.  Medical issues include type 2 diabetes melitus, hypertension, obstructive sleep apnea, and coronary artery disease.  There is marked tenderness over the epigastrium and right upper quadrant with guarding. Bowel sounds are decreased. CECT abdomen is shown below. Which of the following additional intervention is most appropriate in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urgent cholecystectomy

 

The CT scan demonstrates findings consistent with emphysematous cholecystitis, such as gas within the gallbladder wall/lumen and marked pericholecystic inflammation. In the context of sepsis and multiple comorbidities, urgent surgical intervention is necessary, as this severe form of acute cholecystitis carries high risk of perforation and mortality.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Delayed cholecystectomy prior to discharge: Appropriate for uncomplicated cholecystitis, not for severe or complicated cases.
 

Option B. Elective cholecystectomy 2 weeks after complete recovery: Reserved for mild cases, not for emphysematous cholecystitis.
 

Option D. Conservative management: Inappropriate due to evidence of infection with gas-forming organisms and clinical instability.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The child's parents mention that the pain has been increasing over the past few hours. On examination, the child appears distressed and has abdominal tenderness. An X-ray is ordered, and it reveals a gasless abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute Pancreatitis 

 

The clinical presentation of severe abdominal pain and vomiting, along with a gasless abdomen on X-ray, suggests acute pancreatitis. Gasless abdomen is a known radiological sign in early or severe pancreatitis due to paralytic ileus.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Appendicitis: Typically presents with localized right lower quadrant pain; gasless abdomen is uncommon.
 

Option B. Intussusception: Shows characteristic signs like “target sign” on ultrasound and sometimes air-fluid levels on X-ray, not gasless abdomen.
 

Option D. Crohn's disease: Chronic condition with thickened bowel loops; gasless abdomen is not a common feature.

questions.text: A young male presents to surgery OPD with a verrucous lesion over the penis as shown in the image. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the management of choice in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Partial penectomy

 

  • The question depicts a case of verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor.
  • Verrucous carcinoma is a rare type of squamous cell carcinoma that is locally aggressive but has a low potential for metastasis.
  • The lesion typically appears as a large, exophytic, cauliflower-like growth.
  • The management of choice for verrucous carcinoma of the penis is partial penectomy.
  • This surgical procedure involves removing the affected portion of the penis to ensure complete excision of the tumor while preserving as much of the penile structure and function as possible.
  • This approach helps in preventing local recurrence and provides a definitive treatment for the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2 laser ablation: CO2 laser ablation is a treatment option for in-situ carcinoma, such as Bowen’s disease or penile intra-epithelial neoplasm. It is effective in treating superficial lesions but is not adequate for managing verrucous carcinoma due to its deeper and locally invasive nature.

 

Option B. Podophylline: Podophylline is a topical treatment commonly used for genital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). It is not appropriate for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires a more definitive surgical approach.

 

Option C. Topical 5-Fluoro uracil: Topical 5-Fluoro uracil is used in the treatment of in-situ carcinoma or Bowen’s disease. It is not suitable for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires surgical excision due to its locally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor, is best managed by partial penectomy to ensure complete removal of the tumor and prevent local recurrence.
  • This approach is necessary due to the locally aggressive behavior of the tumor, which cannot be adequately treated with topical or minimally invasive methods.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a mobile, rubbery mass in her left breast. A histological image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis for the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibroadenoma

 

The histology image shows well-circumscribed, proliferative stromal and glandular tissue with slit-like spaces, fitting with the classic features of fibroadenoma. Clinically, the description of a mobile, rubbery breast mass in a young female further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Invasive ductal carcinoma: Shows infiltrating malignant epithelial cells with desmoplastic stroma, not the well-organized pattern seen here.

 

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: Displays leaf-like (phyllode) architecture with increased stromal cellularity and atypia, often less circumscribed than fibroadenoma.

 

 

Option D. Lobular carcinoma in-situ: Characterized by small, discohesive cells filling and expanding lobules, lacking the orderly stroma and glandular proliferation

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with rectal bleeding, a change in bowel habits, and tenesmus for 6 months. Examination reveals a mass in the rectum 2 cm from the anal verge extending to the anal sphincters, and biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma. What surgical intervention is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abdominoperineal resection

 

For a rectal adenocarcinoma located within 2 cm of the anal verge and involving the anal sphincters, abdominoperineal resection (APR) is the most appropriate surgical intervention. This procedure involves removal of the rectum, anus, and surrounding tissues with permanent colostomy, ensuring oncologic clearance.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Total mesorectal excision: A surgical technique used as part of low anterior resection or APR but not a standalone procedure.

 

 

Option B. Low anterior resection: Suitable for tumors located higher in the rectum where sphincter preservation is possible.


Option D. Hartmann's procedure: Typically done for obstructed or perforated sigmoid colon, not for low rectal cancers involving sphincters.

questions.text: A young woman presented to the OPD with dysphagia and regurgitation of food. She was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia 3 months back. Barium swallow was done and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plummer-Vinson Syndrome

 

The barium swallow image shows a cervical esophageal web resulting in partial obstruction, and the clinical context includes dysphagia, regurgitation, and a history of iron deficiency anemia. These findings are classic for Plummer-Vinson syndrome[aka Patterson Kelley Syndrome]

 

Other Options:


Option A. Shatzki ring: Typically a lower esophageal (distal) web, not in the cervical esophagus, and not associated with iron deficiency anemia.

 

 

Option B. Zenker's diverticulum: Seen as a posterior outpouching in the pharyngoesophageal area, presenting with regurgitation and halitosis.

 

 

Option C. Esophageal leiomyoma: Appears as a smooth, submucosal mass on imaging, not as a thin mucosal web.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored tarry stools to the OPD. Which of the following structures is the likely site of the bleed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proximal to Ligament of Treitz

 

The image shows melena (dark tarry stool), which is caused by upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The color results from the action of digestive enzymes and bacteria on hemoglobin as blood passes through the GI tract, indicating the source lies proximal to the ligament of Treitz (duodenojejunal flexure).

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Distal to Ligament of Treitz: Bleeding from this region usually presents as hematochezia (fresh blood in stool) rather than melena.
 

Option C. Anal canal: Bleeding here results in bright red blood per rectum.
 

Option D. Sigmoid diverticulosis: Typically causes painless lower GI bleeding, presenting as hematochezia, not melena.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with carcinoma colon underwent USG of the abdomen that showed a hyperechoic lesion in the liver. MRI was performed as shown here. Identify the liver lesion shown on MRI sequence.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemangioma liver

 

The MRI images show a liver lesion with peripheral nodular enhancement and subsequent centripetal fill-in on delayed sequences, typical of a hemangioma. This imaging pattern is pathognomonic for hepatic hemangioma and helps differentiate it from other lesions.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Solitary metastasis: Usually presents as hypovascular lesions with rim enhancement or central necrosis, and doesn't show the classic centripetal enhancement.
 

Option B. Hydatid cyst: Appears as a cystic lesion with daughter cysts and calcified rim, not with nodular peripheral enhancement.
 

Option C. Amoebic liver abscess: Presents as an irregular, hypoechoic lesion with peripheral enhancement, but lacks the lobulated, fill-in pattern of a hemangioma

questions.text: All of the following are components of UW solution except :
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymine

 

Thymine is not a component of the University of Wisconsin (UW) solution.

 

Other components include:

 

  • Allopurinol: A free-radical scavenger that helps reduce oxidative damage.
  • Glutathione: An antioxidant that protects cell membranes during cold storage.
  • Lactobionate: An impermeant that helps maintain osmotic balance and prevents cellular edema.

 

Thus, thymine is the exception and not part of the UW solution composition.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to abdominal discomfort and distension. Five days ago, he began having large-volume watery stools 6-8 times daily after eating at a new restaurant. He self-treated with increased oral fluids and the stool frequency and consistency began to improve. However, his bowel movements abruptly stopped yesterday, and the diffuse abdominal discomfort and distension worsened. The abdomen is distended, tympanic, and mildly tender to palpation with no guarding or rebound tenderness. Bowel sounds are decreased. Abdominal CT scan shows diffuse colonic dilation with nondilated small bowels. Which of the following most likely contributed to this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Electrolyte abnormality 

 

  • This patient has Ogilvie’s syndrome (acute colonic pseudo-obstruction), commonly seen after large-volume diarrhea leading to hypokalemia or other electrolyte disturbances.
  • Electrolyte imbalance, particularly hypokalemia, impairs colonic smooth muscle function, leading to massive colonic dilation.
  • Risk factors include recent illness, hospitalization, medications, and metabolic disturbances.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adhesions: Usually cause small bowel obstruction, not isolated colonic dilation.

 

Option B. Colonic hypoperfusion: Seen in ischemic colitis, typically presents with pain out of proportion, bloody diarrhea, and segmental wall thickening, not diffuse pseudo-obstruction.

 

Option D. Colonic mass: Causes mechanical obstruction, usually segmental, not diffuse colonic dilation with normal small bowel caliber.

choices.text: Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy

questions.text: An 45-year old female comes to your clinic reporting feelings of constant fatigue. Upon performing USG, you discover that she has a scleroatrophic gallbladder containing impacted stones. In addition, a 6mm stone is detected within the common bile duct, causing dilation of the biliary tree. What should be the subsequent course of action in her treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ERCP

 

  • The patient has a common bile duct stone (choledocholithiasis) with biliary dilation, which can lead to cholangitis or pancreatitis if left untreated.
  • Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the first-line therapeutic procedure for CBD stone removal before cholecystectomy.
  • After CBD clearance, elective cholecystectomy is performed to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediately take up patient for cholecystectomy – Performing surgery without addressing the CBD stone risks retained stone complications, including cholangitis or pancreatitis.

 

Option C. Elective cholecystectomy – Correct only after CBD clearance via ERCP; otherwise, patient remains at risk.

 

Option D. MRCP – Diagnostic only; not therapeutic. ERCP both diagnoses and treats CBD stones. Useful when the diagnosis is exact doubtful on USG.

questions.text: A patient who sustained blunt abdominal trauma after a road accident is admitted to the ICU overnight. He is hemodynamically stable. On abdominal examination, he now has tenderness, rigidity, and rebound tenderness. Which is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparotomy

 

  • The patient now shows signs of peritonitis (tenderness, rigidity, rebound), indicating intra-abdominal injury requiring surgical intervention.
  • Even though he was initially stable, the onset of peritoneal signs mandates immediate laparotomy to identify and control internal bleeding or organ injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conservative management – Appropriate only in hemodynamically stable patients without peritoneal signs or organ injury that can be monitored safely. Not suitable once peritonitis develops.

 

Option C. eFAST (extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) – Useful in initial assessment for free fluid/hemoperitoneum, but cannot replace surgery when peritonitis is evident.

 

Option D. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage – Historically used to detect intra-abdominal bleeding; largely superseded by CT or eFAST in stable patients, and unnecessary when clear peritoneal signs indicate immediate laparotomy.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with purulent discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. The patient is put in a lithotomy position and the opening is located at the 11 o'clock position, 4 cm from the anal margin. What will be the likely position of the internal opening?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6 o'clock

 

  • Anorectal fistulas are commonly classified using Goodsall’s rule:
    1. External opening anterior to the transverse anal line → fistula tract runs straight into the anal canal.
    2. External opening posterior to the transverse anal line → fistula tract curves toward the posterior midline (6 o’clock position).
  • In this case, the external opening is posterior (11 o’clock) → the fistula tract starts at the internal opening in the posterior midline (6 o’clock).
  • This explains why most posterior fistulas have their internal opening at 6 o’clock, regardless of lateral position of the external opening.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 12 o’clock – Internal opening at anterior midline; only relevant for anterior external openings.

 

Option B. 11 o’clock – External opening position, not the internal opening; posterior external openings curve toward midline.

 

Option C. 9 o’clock – Lateral posterior, not typical according to Goodsall’s rule; most posterior fistulas terminate at 6 o’clock midline.

 

Goodsall rule:

choices.text: Gastric herniation into the thoracic cavity
Laxity of the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to increasing episodes of nausea and substernal discomfort over the past several months. The episodes frequently occur after eating.  Chest imaging is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastric herniation into the thoracic cavity

 

The chest X-ray shows an air-fluid level behind the heart, consistent with a hiatal hernia. This leads to gastric herniation into the thoracic cavity, causing postprandial nausea and substernal discomfort.

 

Other options:
 

Option A. Degeneration of esophageal ganglion cells: Seen in achalasia, presenting with dysphagia and a dilated esophagus rather than air-fluid levels.
 

Option B. Esophageal metaplastic and dysplastic changes: Associated with Barrett's esophagus and increased malignancy risk, not herniation.
 

Option D. Laxity of the lower esophageal sphincter: Causes gastroesophageal reflux disease, presenting with heartburn, not air-fluid level due to herniation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient suffering from leprosy presents with an ulcer on his foot. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foot care, limb rehabilitation

 

The primary next step in the management of a leprosy-related neuropathic foot ulcer is optimized foot care and limb rehabilitation to prevent further injury, promote wound healing, and protect the anesthetic limb.[corresponds to tertiary prevention]

 

Other options:
 

Option A. Debridement and antibiotics: Indicated if there is evidence of infection or necrotic tissue, but not the immediate next step in a chronic neuropathic ulcer without active infection. .[corresponds to SECONDARY prevention]
 

Option B. Start multi-drug therapy (MDT): Required for active leprosy but does not address ulcer management directly if the patient is already on MDT. [corresponds to SECONDARY prevention]
 

Option D. Deformity correction: Planned after ulcer healing and limb stabilization, not as the first intervention. [corresponds to tertiary prevention]

questions.text: A dye factory worker with a history of benzidine exposure undergoes cystoscopy. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystoscopy with removal of tumor

 

  • This is the diagnostic and therapeutic first-line step.
  • Tissue obtained is sent for histopathology to confirm grade/stage.

 

We’re looking at a cystoscopic image that shows a papillary, exophytic, frond-like growth inside the bladder.

 

The clinical context:

 

  • Patient = dye factory worker → occupational exposure to aromatic amines (e.g., benzidine, β-naphthylamine) → strong risk factor for urothelial carcinoma of the bladder.
  • Lesion = looks like a papillary bladder tumor.
  • First-line management = transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) (here described as “cystoscopy with removal of tumor”).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV BCG: Used in non–muscle invasive bladder cancer after TURBT (as adjuvant). Not the primary step.

 

Option C. TURP (Transurethral resection of prostate): Procedure for benign prostatic hyperplasia, not bladder tumor.

 

Option D. Radical cystectomy: Indicated for muscle-invasive bladder cancer or recurrent high-grade lesions, not the initial step.

questions.text: A 46-year-old female patient undergoes a mammography for a lump in the right breast. Based on the imaging report, she is advised to undergo a biopsy. Which of the following could have been reported?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BIRADS 4b or BIRADS 5 

 

These categories indicate suspicious findings on mammography that strongly warrant a biopsy. BIRADS 4b signifies moderate suspicion of malignancy, while BIRADS 5 suggests a high likelihood of cancer (>95%), necessitating tissue diagnosis through biopsy.

 

Other options:
 

Option A. BIRADS 1 or 2: Negative or benign findings, not warranting biopsy.
 

Option B. BIRADS 2 or 3: Benign or probably benign lesions, with BIRADS 3 usually managed by short-term follow-up rather than biopsy.
 

Option C. BIRADS 3 or 4c: BIRADS 3 usually suggests follow-up; BIRADS 4c has high suspicion but less than 5.

 

Therefore, biopsy is recommended for lesions categorized as BIRADS 4b and above

 

BIRADS ASSESSMENT ALGORITHM:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of swelling and unusual heaviness of his scrotum that he first noticed a few weeks ago. The symptoms improve when he is lying in bed. He also reports a 5-kg weight loss and increasing fatigue over the past 6 months. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of his right flank. There are soft strands palpable in the right hemiscrotum superior of the right testis. The strands increase with Valsalva maneuver. Applying a bright light to the right hemiscrotum shows no transillumination. Obstruction of venous drainage into which of the following vessels is most likely responsible for this patient's scrotal enlargement?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inferior vena cava

 

  • The patient has a right-sided varicocele (soft strands above testis, increases with Valsalva, non-transilluminating).
  • Sudden-onset or adult varicocele on the right side in a patient >40 years suggests secondary varicocele due to obstruction of venous drainage, commonly from retroperitoneal mass compressing the IVC (renal cell carcinoma, retroperitoneal tumor).
  • Right testicular vein drains directly into the IVC, whereas the left drains into the left renal vein. Hence IVC obstruction affects the right side predominantly.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Right internal iliac vein: Drains the pelvis; unlikely to cause isolated right-sided varicocele.

 

Option B. Right inferior rectal vein: Drains anorectal region; obstruction would cause hemorrhoids, not varicocele.

 

Option C. Right renal vein: Left-sided varicoceles are more commonly associated with left renal vein compression (Nutcracker syndrome), not right-sided.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of pain in the calf muscles after walking for a certain distance. The pain is relieved by rest and reoccurs upon resuming walking. Based on Boyd’s classification, what is the most likely grade?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grade III

 

Boyd’s classification is used to grade peripheral arterial disease (PAD) based on clinical symptoms:

 

 

The patient experiences calf pain after walking a certain distance, relieved by rest, fitting Grade III (moderate claudication).

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Annual risk of adenocarcinoma in Barrett’s esophagus with low grade dysplasia is 0.7% per year.
  2. The iliohypogastric nerve is most commonly injured during Rutherford-Morrison incision
  3. Replaced left hepatic artery arising from superior mesenteric artery is the most common vascular anomaly of the liver. 
  4. Malignant melanoma in the last 5 years is a contraindication to renal transplant
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Statement 1. Annual risk of adenocarcinoma in Barrett’s esophagus with low-grade dysplasia is 0.7% per year: Correct. Barrett’s esophagus with low-grade dysplasia carries a modest but significant risk of progression to adenocarcinoma (~0.5–1% per year).

 

Statement 2. The iliohypogastric nerve is most commonly injured during Rutherford-Morrison incision: Correct. The Rutherford-Morrison incision (used for lower abdominal/pelvic surgeries) crosses the course of the iliohypogastric nerve, making it the most commonly injured nerve in this approach.

 

Statement 4. Malignant melanoma in the last 5 years is a contraindication to renal transplant: Correct.Recent history of aggressive malignancy, especially melanoma, is a contraindication to immunosuppression due to high risk of recurrence.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 3. Replaced left hepatic artery arising from SMA is the most common vascular anomaly of the liver: Incorrect. The most common hepatic arterial anomaly is a replaced right hepatic artery arising from the superior mesenteric artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the treatment of a patient who presented with the following as shown in the image? Earlier the abdominal mass was reducible, but now it has become irreducible. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical excision with herniorrhaphy

 

The clinical scenario presented is that of an umbilical hernia that was previously reducible but has now become irreducible. This suggests the hernia has become complicated, possibly due to incarceration or strangulation, where the contents are trapped, leading to ischemia or gangrene of the herniated tissue. The overlying skin also appears gangrenous and requires excision.

 

The correct management involves surgical intervention to excise the affected umbilical tissue and perform herniorrhaphy, which is a repair of the hernia without the use of a mesh, particularly when there are complications such as strangulation or infection. The surgical approach must address both the excision of compromised tissue and the closure of the hernial defect to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical excision: This option only addresses the excision of the skin and does not treat the underlying hernia. Simply excising the umbilical tissue will not resolve the hernia defect or prevent recurrence, making this option inadequate.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone are not a definitive treatment for a hernia. While antibiotics may be used if there is an associated infection, they do not resolve the underlying mechanical problem of a hernia.

 

Option D. Incision and drainage: This procedure is appropriate for abscesses and localized infections but not for hernias. There is no indication of an abscess in this scenario; rather, it is a hernia with possible ischemic or gangrenous changes, requiring surgical repair rather than drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of complicated umbilical hernias, especially when the hernia becomes irreducible, surgical intervention with umbilical excision and herniorrhaphy is necessary to repair the hernia and prevent further complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thoracoscore? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Complication of Surgery

 

This is not a component of Thoracoscore. While complications of surgery can impact outcomes, they are not a predefined parameter in the Thoracoscore risk model.

 

The complication of surgery is not a component of Thoracoscore.

 

Thoracoscore is a risk model used to predict the probability of death within 30 days following thoracic surgery. The model takes into account the following nine parameters:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Performance status: This is a component of Thoracoscore. Poorer performance status is associated with a higher risk.

 

Option C. ASA grading: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The ASA score is used to assess the physical status and associated risk of patients undergoing surgery.

 

Option D. Priority of surgery: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The urgency of the surgery (elective vs. emergent) affects the risk of postoperative complications and mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracoscore is a predictive risk model for mortality within 30 days following thoracic surgery. It includes parameters such as age, sex, performance status, dyspnea score, ASA score, cardiovascular comorbidity, surgical procedure extent, cancer status, and urgency of surgery, but does not include the complication of surgery as a predefined parameter.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and discomfort for the past few months. On evaluation, a mass is palpable in the upper abdomen, and an endoscopy shows an ulcerated lesion in the stomach. A biopsy of the lesion is taken and sent for immunohistochemistry. The biopsy sample is found to be positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100. CT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GIST

 

The most likely diagnosis is gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST), based on the finding of a gastric mass with an ulcerated lesion, immunohistochemical positivity for CD117 (c-KIT), and negativity for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100—markers that help differentiate GIST from lymphomas, carcinomas, and neural tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: This is the most common type of gastric cancer arising from the epithelial lining. It typically shows positive staining for cytokeratin and presents with ulcerative or infiltrative lesions on endoscopy, unlike GIST which is CD117 positive.

 

Option C. Hodgkin’s lymphoma: A malignant lymphoid neoplasm usually positive for LCA (leukocyte common antigen). Gastric involvement is rare and would present with lymphoid tissue proliferation, unlike the spindle or epithelioid cells seen in GIST.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: Rare in the stomach, it arises from squamous epithelium and expresses cytokeratin but not CD117. It usually presents as an ulcerated mass but lacks the specific immunohistochemical profile of GIST.

questions.text: In extended right hemi-hepatectomy, the liver segments resected are:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4-8

 

  • Couinaud’s classification divides the liver into 8 segments (1 = caudate lobe).
  • Right hepatectomy = removal of segments 5, 6, 7, 8.
  • Extended right hepatectomy (also called right trisectionectomy) = removal of segments 4, 5, 6, 7, 8.
    • Includes both right lobe + segment 4 (medial left lobe).
    • Leaves behind segments 1, 2, 3.
  • Other resections for context:
    • Left hepatectomy = 2, 3, 4
    • Extended left hepatectomy = 2, 3, 4, 5, 8
    • Central hepatectomy = 4, 5, 8

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of recurrent thumb pain that worsens with exposure to cold temperatures. Examination shows a 6-mm, blue-red papule under the left thumbnail. The overlying area is extremely tender to palpation. The thumbnail is slightly pitted and cracked. This lesion most likely developed from which of the following types of cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Modified smooth muscle cells

 

  • The patient presents with a glomus tumor, a benign tumor of the glomus body, commonly found under the nail (subungual).
  • Classic features: extreme tenderness, paroxysmal pain, cold sensitivity, blue-red subungual papule.
  • Glomus bodies are modified smooth muscle cells involved in thermoregulation by controlling blood flow in the skin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysplastic melanocytes: Associated with melanoma, which may be pigmented, irregular, and not typically exquisitely tender or cold-sensitive.

 

Option B. Capillary endothelial cells: Found in hemangiomas; these are usually soft, compressible, and not extremely painful or cold-sensitive.

 

Option D. Osteoclasts: Involved in bone resorption, not the origin of subungual painful lesions like glomus tumors.

questions.text: When considering a patient with lung cancer, the imaging studies have measured the tumor size at 2.5 cm not invading in to the main bronchus. According to the TMN staging system, which stage would be appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T1

 

  • T-staging for lung cancer (8th edition, AJCC):

 

 

Explanation:

 

  • Tumor is 2.5 cm, not invading main bronchus → falls in T1c (subset of T1).
  • For simplicity, in many MCQs, T1 is accepted for tumors ≤3 cm confined to the lung without main bronchus involvement.

choices.text: Left gastric vein and azygos vein
Paraumbilical vein and inferior epigastric vein
Portal vein and inferior vena cava
Splenic vein and left renal vein

questions.text: A 57-year-old white man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of sudden-onset, bright red emesis. His blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg and heart rate is 124/min. Physical examination is notable for jaundice and an enlarged abdomen that is dull to percussion and positive for a fluid wave. Which of the following vessel anastomoses is responsible for the patient’s bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left gastric vein and azygos vein

 

  • The patient has hematemesis in the setting of portal hypertension (jaundice, ascites).
  • Esophageal varices are the most common cause of upper GI bleeding in cirrhosis.
  • Esophageal varices arise from portosystemic anastomosis between the left gastric vein (portal system) and azygos vein (systemic circulation).
  • Rupture leads to massive, bright red hematemesis and hypovolemic shock.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Paraumbilical vein and inferior epigastric vein: Form caput medusae; superficial abdominal varices, rarely bleed massively.

 

Option C. Portal vein and inferior vena cava: There is no direct anastomosis causing variceal bleeding; portal hypertension leads to collateral formation instead.

 

Option D. Splenic vein and left renal vein: Forms gastric or short gastric varices; less common and usually in splenic vein thrombosis, not general cirrhosis.

choices.text: Infant is at least 10 weeks old
Hemoglobin level of 10 grams per deciliter

questions.text: Millard's Rule of 10 for indications of cleft lip surgery include all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Defect is 10 mm

 

  • Millard’s Rule of 10 is a safety guideline for timing cleft lip repair:
  1. Age ≥ 10 weeks
  2. Weight ≥ 10 pounds (~4.5 kg)
  3. Hemoglobin ≥ 10 g/dL
  • There is no criterion regarding the size of the cleft (10 mm).
  • The rule ensures the infant is physiologically stable to tolerate anesthesia and surgery safely.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Infant is at least 10 weeks old: Correct, ensures adequate maturity and reduced anesthesia risk.

 

Option B. Infant weighs around 10 pounds: Correct, adequate weight reduces perioperative complications.

 

Option C. Hemoglobin level of 10 grams per deciliter: Correct, ensures sufficient oxygen-carrying capacity during surgery.

questions.text: A patient following head injury with altered consciousness, vomiting, and GCS of 10/15 undergoes CT scan as shown. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompression

 

The CT scan shows a large, hyperdense, crescent-shaped lesion consistent with an acute subdural hematoma causing significant midline shift.
