In a patient with decreased consciousness (GCS 10/15) and signs of raised intracranial pressure, urgent surgical decompression (craniotomy or burr hole evacuation) is the next step.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. IV Mannitol: May be used as a temporizing measure to reduce intracranial pressure but does not address the underlying hematoma requiring surgical evacuation.
 

Option B. Wait and watch: Not appropriate due to evidence of mass effect, midline shift, and impaired consciousness; delay risks irreversible neurological damage.
 

Option D. IV thrombolytic: Contraindicated in intracranial bleed as it may worsen hemorrhage.

questions.text: An intra-operative image of scrotal exploration in a 18 year old male with acute scrotal pain is shown. Identify the pathology.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Torsion of Hydatid of Morgagni

 

The image shows a blue-black nodule (arrow) at the upper pole of the testis, which is characteristic of the torsion of the hydatid of Morgagni (appendix testis). This is a vestigial remnant and its torsion leads to acute scrotal pain, especially in adolescents.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Testicular torsion: Presents with twisted spermatic cord and non-viable, dusky testis, not limited to a small torsion nodule.
 

Option C. Epididymo-orchitis: Shows an enlarged, inflamed epididymis and testis but not a localized dark nodule.
 

Option D. Testicular hematoma: Appears as a collection of blood within the testis rather than a discrete nodule at the pole.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with bleeding during defecation and straining. Examination reveals pile mass which appears on straining, at 7 and 11 O'clock, which reduces spontaneously.  Preferred treatment:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barron’s Banding

 

Barron’s band ligation is the preferred and effective treatment for internal hemorrhoids that prolapse during straining but reduce spontaneously, typically grades II and III. It is a minimally invasive outpatient procedure with a high success rate and quick recovery.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy: Usually reserved for higher-grade hemorrhoids with significant prolapse; more invasive and costly.
 

Option C. Milligan Morgan procedure: An open hemorrhoidectomy, used for large, symptomatic, or thrombosed hemorrhoids, not usually first-line for reducible piles. Image shown below demonstrates the procedure.
 

Option D. Sitz bath: A conservative measure to relieve symptoms but does not treat prolapsed hemorrhoids effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barron’s banding treats the underlying prolapse and bleeding effectively with minimal discomfort and downtime

choices.text: Ileocolic, right colic and branch of middle colic
Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic
Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has been diagnosed with proximal transverse colon carcinoma. The physician recommends an extended right colectomy as a treatment option. Which arteries should be resected during an extended right colectomy to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

 

During an extended right colectomy for proximal transverse colon carcinoma, the arterial supply from the ileocolic artery, right colic artery, and the main trunk of the middle colic artery must be ligated and resected. This ensures complete lymphovascular clearance to prevent the spread of cancer.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Ileocolic, right colic and branch of middle colic: Not sufficient, as only the branch is resected, missing the main trunk.
 

Option B. Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic: Includes left colic, which is not part of the right-sided resection territory.
 

Option D. Middle colic only: Does not address the ileocolic and right colic arteries supplying the right colon and proximal transverse colon.

questions.text: A 80-year-old male patient presents with a PSA level of 7 ng/mL and a small tumor focus in prostate with a Gleason score of 6, what would be the most appropriate course of action for management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Active surveillance

 

For a patient with a PSA of 7 ng/mL and a low-volume, low-grade tumor (Gleason score 6), active surveillance is the most appropriate management. This approach involves regular monitoring with PSA testing, digital rectal exams, and repeat biopsies to avoid overtreatment and its side effects when the tumor is likely indolent.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Radical prostatectomy: Reserved for higher-grade tumors or those with significant progression risk; unnecessary for low-risk disease.
 

Option B. External beam radiation: Suitable for intermediate to high-risk prostate cancer but not first-line in low-risk cases.
 

Option C. Brachytherapy: Also used for localized prostate cancer with higher risk; less preferred for low Gleason score tumors managed conservatively.

 

Current guidelines recommend active surveillance for men with low PSA, low Gleason score tumors, especially older patients or those with comorbidities, to balance treatment benefit and quality of life

choices.text: Start prophylactic LMWH to avoid risk of DVT
Use regional anesthetics and nonopioid analgesics
Avoid prolonged fasting before surgery and prewarm fluids

questions.text: All of the following are components of ERAS Protocol (Enhanced Recovery After Surgery) except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start prophylactic LMWH to avoid risk of DVT

 

  • ERAS Protocol focuses on optimizing perioperative care to enhance recovery, reduce complications, and shorten hospital stay.
  • Key components:
    • Goal-directed fluid therapy (avoid over-resuscitation, not active aggressive IV fluids)
    • Multimodal analgesia using regional blocks and nonopioid analgesics
    • Early feeding, reduced fasting, prewarming fluids, early mobilization
  • Prophylactic LMWH is part of DVT prophylaxis, which is important but not a core ERAS component; ERAS emphasizes minimizing perioperative stress and enhancing recovery, not anticoagulation protocols specifically.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Avoid Active IV fluid resuscitation: ERAS recommends goal-directed or restrictive fluid management, not liberal resuscitation.

 

Option C. Use regional anesthetics and nonopioid analgesics: Correct, reduces opioid use, promotes early mobilization.

 

Option D. Avoid prolonged fasting and prewarm fluids: Correct, prevents catabolic state, hypothermia, and improves postoperative outcomes.

 

ERAS prorocol components:

questions.text: Identify the device in the image: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PEG tube

 

The image provided shows a tray containing various instruments, including an introducer, a tube with a bolster, and a guide wire, which are characteristic of a PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) tube kit. A PEG tube is used for providing nutrition directly into the stomach in patients who cannot swallow food. The distinguishing features of a PEG tube include a retention bolster that secures the tube to the abdominal wall and an inflatable balloon at the end that helps retain the tube within the stomach. The presence of these components in the tray confirms that the  is a PEG tube. This procedure involves making a small incision in the abdomen, inserting the tube, and securing it, which is why the tray includes various tools for this process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NJ tube (Nasojejunal tube): An NJ tube is inserted through the nose and extends into the jejunum. It is typically used for feeding but does not require the surgical kit or bolster shown in the image.

 

 

Option C. NG tube (Nasogastric tube): An NG tube is a simple tube inserted through the nose into the stomach or intestine. Unlike the PEG tube, it does not involve a retention bolster or a complex insertion procedure, making it less likely to require the tools seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Chest drain tube: A chest drain tube is used to remove air, fluid, or pus from the pleural space in the chest. It typically does not include the bolster and balloon characteristic of a PEG tube, and the tools in the image do not match those used for chest drainage procedures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The PEG tube is a specialized device used for long-term feeding directly into the stomach, identified by its retention bolster and the presence of specific tools in the insertion kit. Understanding the key components of the PEG tube kit helps differentiate it from other types of medical tubes

choices.text: Repair with great saphenous vein graft

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient arrives at the emergency department with a history of stabbing injury to her arm. Upon examination, there is a noticeable hematoma, and the patient reports not feeling any radial or ulnar pulses in the affected arm. Imaging reveals a 3cm longitudinal tear in the brachial artery. The medical team is faced with deciding the best treatment option for the patient. Which option should they choose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repair with great saphenous vein graft 

 

  • The patient has significant arterial injury with absent distal pulses, indicating limb-threatening ischemia.
  • The brachial artery tear is 3 cm, which is too long for primary end-to-end repair without tension.
  • Autologous vein graft (great saphenous vein) is preferred:
    • Readily available
    • Superior long-term patency
    • Less risk of infection compared to prosthetic grafts in trauma
  • Prosthetic grafts are reserved for contaminated fields or when vein grafts are unavailable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary repair with end-to-end anastomosis: Not feasible here; tension-free repair is essential, and 3 cm defect is too long.

 

Option C. Repair with prosthetic graft: Higher risk of infection and thrombosis in traumatic contaminated wounds; less preferred.

 

Option D. Repair with IMA (internal mammary artery): Not practical or standard for brachial artery repair; IMA is small and anatomically distant.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about inguinal hernias are true? 

 

  1. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by gonadal vessels
  2. Lateral border of the triangle of pain is bound by Iliopubic tract. 
  3. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by rectus abdominis.
  4. Lateral border of myopectineal orifice is bound by iliopsoas
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 2. Lateral border of the triangle of pain is bound by Iliopubic tract: True.

 

  • The triangle of pain is bounded superiorly by iliopubic tract and medially by the gonadal vessels.
  • It contains important nerves (lateral femoral cutaneous, femoral branch of genitofemoral).

 

Statement 3. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by rectus abdominis: True.

 

  • The myopectineal orifice of Fruchaud is a weak area bounded:
    • Medially by rectus abdominis
    • Laterally by iliopsoas
    • Superiorly by arch of transversus abdominis
    • Inferiorly by pectineal ligament

 

Statement 4. Lateral border of myopectineal orifice is bound by iliopsoas: True. Correct, as explained above.

 

False Statement:

 

Statement 1. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by gonadal vessels – False

 

  • The triangle of doom is bounded medially by the vas deferens and laterally by gonadal vessels.
  • So the medial border is not gonadal vessels.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with severe abdominal distension, pain for the past two days. Physical examination reveals a distended, tympanic abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caecal volvulus

 

The abdominal X-ray demonstrates a massively dilated bowel loop in the right lower abdomen with a "kidney-shaped" appearance, consistent with caecal volvulus. The clinical context of acute severe distension and pain further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Small bowel volvulus: Would typically show multiple distended, centrally located small bowel loops, not a solitary large caecal loop.
 

Option B. Intestinal obstruction: Presents with multiple dilated loops and air-fluid levels, but the classic kidney-shaped loop is not seen.
 

Option C. Sigmoid volvulus: Usually presents as a large, coffee-bean shaped loop towards the left upper quadrant.

questions.text: All of the following are correct about ACS guidelines for average-risk population for colorectal carcinoma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Colonoscopy every 5 years

 

  • Reasoning:
  • According to ACS (American Cancer Society) guidelines for average-risk adults:
    • Start screening at 45–50 years
    • FOBT or FIT: annually
    • Flexible sigmoidoscopy: every 5 years
    • Colonoscopy: every 10 years, not 5 years
  • Colonoscopy allows visualization of the entire colon and polyp removal, so it is the preferred modality, but 10-year interval is recommended if normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Begin screening at 50 years: Correct. some guidelines now suggest 45 years.

 

Option B. Annual FOBT: Correct. non-invasive test for occult bleeding.

 

Option C. Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years: Correct. visualizes distal colon, can be combined with FOBT.

questions.text: During total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, which of the following steps will not lead to hoarseness of voice?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ligation of Superior thyroid artery

 

  • Hoarseness of voice after thyroidectomy is usually caused by injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN).
  • Steps at risk for RLN injury:
    • Beahr’s triangle dissection – RLN passes through, risk of traction or injury.
    • Zuckerkandl tubercle dissection – RLN often passes posterior or medial; risk during excision.
    • Berry ligament dissection – RLN runs very close to ligament; common site of injury.
  • Ligation of superior thyroid artery – Only risk to external branch of superior laryngeal nerve, which affects pitch, not causing true hoarseness of voice; careful ligation near the superior pole avoids injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dissection of Beahr’s triangle[shown below]: High risk of RLN injury → hoarseness.

 

Option B. Dissection of Zuckerkandl tubercle: RLN closely related → hoarseness possible.

 

Option C. Dissection of Berry ligament: RLN passes adjacent → high risk of hoarseness.

choices.text: Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up

questions.text: A 63-year-old female patient presented with a 5x1 cm lump in the left upper outer quadrant, with no axillary lymph node involvement. Mammography revealed BIRADS 4b staging. She underwent breast conservation surgery, and the final HE reports showed high nuclear grade DCIS with 7 mm margin clearance. What is the further management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

After breast-conserving surgery (BCS) for ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), adjuvant radiotherapy is typically recommended. Radiotherapy has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of local recurrence after BCS for DCIS. In this patient, despite having a 7 mm margin clearance, the presence of high nuclear grade DCIS warrants the use of adjuvant radiotherapy to minimize the risk of local recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adjuvant chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is primarily used for invasive breast cancers, especially when there is a high risk of systemic spread. DCIS is a non-invasive form of breast cancer, and hence systemic chemotherapy is not typically indicated.

 

Option C. Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up: Regular follow-up is crucial for any patient who has undergone treatment for breast cancer, but it is not the primary management strategy immediately after surgery for high nuclear grade DCIS.

 

Option D. Trastuzumab therapy: Trastuzumab is a targeted therapy used for HER2-positive invasive breast cancers. DCIS that is HER2-positive does not typically receive trastuzumab therapy, as the benefits of such treatment in non-invasive cancer have not been clearly established.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on the Van Nuys prognostic index, the patient’s score is: High grade- 3 points, Margins 7 mm-2 points, Size 5 cm- 3 points and age 63 years- 1 point= 9 points.

 

The recommended next step in the patient's management would be adjuvant radiotherapy for scores 7 to 9.

 

 

Score: 4 to 6: wide excision alone

 

7 to 9: Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

10 to 12: Mastectomy

choices.text: Broad spectrum antibiotics to cover GNB

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with weight loss and fever. The patient reports a history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago. Upon examination, tenderness is noted in the right hypochondrium along with an enlarged liver. An abdominal CT scan is shown below. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Start metronidazole

 

The CT scan shows a liver lesion with characteristic peripheral enhancement and central hypodensity, consistent with an amoebic liver abscess. The most appropriate initial management is to start metronidazole, which is highly effective against Entamoeba histolytica.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Broad spectrum antibiotics to cover GNB: Indicated for pyogenic liver abscess (bacterial), not amoebic.


Option C. PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Re-aspiration): Appropriate for hydatid cysts, not amoebic abscess.


Option D. Pigtail drainage: Reserved for large abscesses at risk of rupture or not responding to medical therapy.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SADI-S

 

The image illustrates the Single Anastomosis Duodeno-Ileal bypass with Sleeve gastrectomy (SADI-S) procedure. This surgery involves creating a sleeve gastrectomy (removal of part of the stomach, leaving a gastric pouch) followed by an end-to-side duodeno-ileostomy, connecting the proximal duodenum to the distal ileum, thus altering both food and digestive juice flow.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Sleeve gastrectomy: Involves only resection of the stomach without intestinal bypass.


Option C. Roux-en-Y gastric bypass: Features a small gastric pouch with separate Roux and biliopancreatic limbs and a gastrojejunal anastomosis.


Option D. Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch: Involves both sleeve gastrectomy and duodenal-ileal bypass but typically with a different anatomical configuration and limb lengths.

 

Images given below denote the procedures mentioned above

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the ERCP image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliary ascariasis

 

The ERCP image typically shows elongated, linear filling defects within the biliary ducts, consistent with the presence of adult Ascaris worms. This is characteristic of biliary ascariasis, where the parasite migrates into the bile ducts causing biliary obstruction.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Choledochal cyst: Would show cystic dilatation of the bile ducts rather than linear filling defects.

 

Option C. Caroli disease: Characterized by saccular or fusiform intrahepatic bile duct dilatation with a "central dot" sign, not seen as linear intraductal filling defects.


Option D. Choledocholithiasis: Shows discrete filling defects caused by calculi, which are usually round or oval, not elongated like worms.

 

Thus, the diagnosis based on ERCP findings is biliary ascariasis.

questions.text: Identify the suture:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Horizontal mattress

 

The image shows a suture technique where each suture pass enters and exits the skin on either side of the wound, with a second pass made parallel to the first, creating a horizontal loop across the wound, characteristic of the horizontal mattress suture.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Vertical mattress: Passes in a far-near-near-far fashion, but the loops are vertical across the wound.


Option C. Interrupted: Each suture is tied separately, without loops or passes across the wound.


Option D. Continuous: A running suture without individual knotting between passes.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented with pain and tightness on the glans penis and pigmentation with difficulty in urination. Examination finding is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Balanitis xerotica

 

The image depicts white, atrophic, sclerotic patches affecting the glans penis with ulceration and difficulty in retracting the foreskin, suggestive of balanitis xerotica obliterans (also termed lichen sclerosus), a chronic inflammatory condition causing pain, tightening, and urinary symptoms.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Condyloma acuminata: Presents as exophytic, warty lesions due to HPV infection, usually not ulcerative or sclerotic.


Option C. Erythroplasia of Queyrat (EQ): Appears as a red, velvety plaque on the glans, not as white sclerosed tissue.


Option D. Peyronie’s disease: Characterized by fibrous plaques in the tunica albuginea causing penile curvature, not cutaneous or mucosal lesions.

questions.text: In a patient with hyperplasia of all four parathyroid glands who undergoes total parathyroidectomy followed by implantation of parathyroid tissue in a different site, which term best defines this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterotopic

 

  • Heterotopic autotransplantation refers to implanting parathyroid tissue at a different site (commonly forearm or sternocleidomastoid) after total parathyroidectomy.
  • Done to preserve some parathyroid function while removing hyperfunctioning glands.
  • This differs from orthotopic (implantation at the original site) and isograft (graft between genetically identical individuals).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isograft: Incorrect. involves grafting tissue between genetically identical individuals, not autotransplantation.

 

Option B. Auxiliary: Incorrect. auxiliary graft usually refers to an additional tissue placed alongside a main organ, not the standard parathyroid transplantation.

 

Option D. Orthotopic: Incorrect. refers to reimplantation at the original anatomical location, not a different site.

choices.text: Increased ACTH and cortisol levels are characteristic findings
Insulin levels are elevated in the ebb phase of stress
There is increased hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipolysis
Growth hormone (GH) and TNF-α levels are elevated

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the metabolic and hormonal response to surgical stress/trauma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insulin levels are elevated in the ebb phase of stress

 

  • The ebb phase occurs immediately after trauma and is characterized by low cardiac output, hypotension, and hypometabolism.
  • Insulin levels are actually decreased, leading to hyperglycemia and insulin resistance in the later flow phase.
  • Cortisol, catecholamines, GH, and TNF-α increase to maintain metabolic homeostasis and mobilize energy substrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased ACTH and cortisol levels are characteristic findings: Correct. these hormones rise to counteract stress and promote gluconeogenesis.

 

Option C. There is Increased hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipolysis: Correct. ensures energy supply for vital organs.

 

Option D. Growth hormone (GH) and TNF-α levels elevated: Correct. GH promotes protein mobilization, TNF-α is part of inflammatory response.

questions.text: All of the following are contraindications for PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Re-aspiration) in hydatid cyst except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) WHO type CE1 cyst

 

  • PAIR is safely indicated in simple, unilocular cysts (CE1) without communication with biliary or bronchial tree.
  • Contraindications include multivesicular cysts, cysts communicating with bile ducts, or pulmonary cysts, due to risk of spillage or anaphylaxis.
  • CE1 cysts are early, active, fluid-filled, unilocular cysts – ideal candidates for PAIR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Honeycomb cysts with multiple septae: Contraindicated. septations increase risk of incomplete evacuation and recurrence.

 

Option B. Cysts communicating with bile duct: Contraindicated; risk of biliary leakage and cholangitis.

 

Option D. Pulmonary hydatid cyst: Contraindicated; risk of pneumothorax, spillage, and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which of these open inguinal hernia repairs involves double breasting of conjoint tendon with inguinal ligament?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shouldice’s repair

 

  • Shouldice's repair is an open inguinal hernia repair involving the following steps:
    1. The conjoint tendon is sutured to the inguinal ligament in multiple overlapping (double-breasting) layers.
    2. This technique strengthens the posterior wall of the inguinal canal using continuous sutures.
    3. It is considered a pure tissue repair, meaning no prosthetic mesh is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bassini’s repair:

 

  • In Bassini’s repair, the conjoint tendon is approximated to the inguinal ligament in a single layer.
  • This technique does not involve double-breasting and is simpler compared to Shouldice repair.

 

Option B. Maloney’s repair

 

  • Maloney’s repair is a variation of hernia repair, but it does not involve the double-breasting of tissue layers.
  • It is not as commonly practiced as other techniques.

 

Option D. Desarda’s repair:

 

  • Desarda’s repair uses a strip of external oblique aponeurosis, which is sutured to the conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament to reinforce the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • It functions dynamically by tightening during abdominal muscle contraction, but it does not involve double-breasting of the conjoint tendon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shouldice repair is a tissue-based open inguinal hernia repair involving double-breasting of the conjoint tendon with the inguinal ligament. 
  • This technique is recognized for its superior outcomes and low recurrence rates compared to other tissue repairs.

questions.text: All of the following tumor classifications are correctly matched with their associated tumors except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gleason scoring – Testicular cancer

 

  • Gleason scoring is used for prostate cancer, not testicular cancer.
  • Bloom–Richardson grading: histologic grading for breast carcinoma.
  • Duke staging: classic staging for colorectal carcinoma.
  • Masaoka staging: staging system for thymoma, based on invasion and spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bloom–Richardson grading – Carcinoma breast: Correct. evaluates tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic count.

 

Option B. Duke staging – Colorectal carcinoma: Correct. early classification for colorectal cancer prognosis.

 

Option D. Masaoka staging – Thymoma: Correct. assesses capsular invasion and metastasis.

questions.text: A female with ER+, PR+, HER2- breast cancer is to be treated. Which of the following is the most recently approved agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Palbociclib

 

  • Palbociclib is a CDK4/6 inhibitor approved for ER+, PR+, HER2- advanced breast cancer.
  • Works by blocking cell cycle progression from G1 to S phase.
  • Improves progression-free survival when combined with endocrine therapy.
  • Herceptin targets HER2-positive tumors; not indicated in HER2- cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ipatasertib: AKT inhibitor; still under investigation, not standard for ER+ HER2- breast cancer.

 

Option B. Buparlisib: PI3K inhibitor; early-phase studies, not widely approved.

 

Option D. Herceptin:  Trastuzumab; only effective in HER2-positive breast cancer.

questions.text:
Breast conservation surgery is feasible in which of the following patients with breast carcinoma?

 

  1. A post-partum woman
  2. Small breast with a large tumor
  3. Persistently positive margin
  4. Diffuse microcalcification on mammogram
  5. Prior chest radiation
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Only 1

 

  • BCS feasibility depends on:
    • Tumor-to-breast ratio – large tumor in small breast → poor cosmetic outcome.
    • Margins – persistently positive margins contraindicate BCS.
    • Diffuse microcalcifications – usually require mastectomy.
    • Prior chest radiation – increases risk of poor healing and fibrosis.
  • Statement 1. A post-partum woman: With appropriately sized tumor and clear margins can undergo BCS safely.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 2. Small breast with large tumor: Incorrect. poor cosmetic result, usually requires mastectomy.

 

Statement 3. Persistently positive margin: Incorrect. BCS cannot ensure complete tumor excision.

 

Statement 4. Diffuse microcalcification on mammogram: Incorrect. widespread involvement usually requires mastectomy.

 

Statement 5. Prior chest radiation: Incorrect. increased complication risk post-BCS

questions.text: Identify the type of injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Closed degloving injury

 

The image shows the separation of skin and subcutaneous tissue from underlying fascia, with a collection of blood beneath intact skin, which is classic for a closed degloving injury (e.g., Morel-Lavallée lesion).

 

Other Options:


Option B. Incised looking laceration: Involves an open wound with clean edges, not the intact skin seen here.


Option C. Subcutaneous hematoma: Features localized blood collection, but without the large plane of tissue separation shown.


Option D. Flaying laceration: Refers to open degloving injuries with exposed subcutaneous tissue.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with hematuria and left flank pain. Imaging studies reveal a renal mass, and a subsequent biopsy confirms the diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is most characteristic of papillary chromophilic renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trisomy 7/17

 

  • Papillary RCC (chromophilic type) is most commonly associated with trisomy of chromosomes 7 and 17 and loss of Y in males.
  • This contrasts with clear cell RCC, which is commonly linked to loss of 3p and VHL gene mutations.
  • Xp translocations are characteristic of MiT family translocation RCC, seen mainly in children and young adults.
  • Cytogenetic profiling helps in diagnosis, prognosis, and targeted therapy planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Loss of 3p: Incorrect. typical of clear cell RCC, seen in VHL syndrome.

 

Option C. Xp translocation: Incorrect. seen in translocation-associated RCC, mostly in pediatric patients.

 

Option D. Mutant VHL gene: Incorrect. hallmark of clear cell RCC, leading to HIF pathway activation.

choices.text: Condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern
Risk of colon cancer is nearly 100%

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy undergoing ophthalmoscopy shows pigmentary changes. Family history reveals colon and endometrial cancers. APC gene mutation is confirmed. Which statement is incorrect about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mutation is located on chromosome 15

 

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), suggested by the pigmented retinal lesions (CHRPE) and strong family history of colon and endometrial cancer, is caused by mutation in the APC gene on chromosome 5.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern: True. FAP follows AD inheritance.

 

Option C. Risk of colon cancer is nearly 100%: True. almost all untreated FAP patients develop colorectal cancer.

 

Option D. Prophylactic surgery is recommended: True. colectomy is often recommended to prevent cancer progression.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the hospital due to erectile dysfunction.  A palpable plaque is present on the dorsal side of the penis approximately halfway between the glans and the pubis. The testes are normal with no scrotal erythema or skin ulceration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peyronie disease

 

  • Peyronie disease is characterized by fibrous plaque formation in the tunica albuginea of the penis, often leading to penile curvature, pain, and erectile dysfunction.
  • Lesions are typically palpable, dorsal, and midway along the shaft, as in this patient.
  • Genital warts are soft, verrucous lesions and rarely cause plaques or erectile dysfunction.
  • Penile cancer usually presents as ulcerative or nodular lesions, often with skin changes.
  • Systemic sclerosis can cause skin thickening and telangiectasia, but plaques localized to the penis are uncommon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Genital warts: Incorrect. caused by HPV, present as soft papules or clusters, not firm plaques, and usually painless.

 

Option B. Penile cancer: Incorrect. typically presents as a non-healing ulcer or nodule, often with pain, bleeding, or skin changes.

 

Option D. Systemic sclerosis: Incorrect. causes diffuse skin thickening and microvascular changes, rarely isolated penile plaques.

questions.text: What is the procedure being shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Billroth II reconstruction

 

The image shows a surgical procedure in which the distal stomach is resected and the gastric remnant is anastomosed to the side of the jejunum, bypassing the duodenum, which is characteristic of Billroth II (gastrojejunostomy) reconstruction.

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Billroth I reconstruction: Involves gastroduodenostomy, connecting the stomach to the duodenum.


Option C. Braun anastomosis: An additional side-to-side jejunojejunostomy, not visualized here.

 

 

Option D. Roux-en Y gastrojejunostomy: Features a Y-shaped configuration, with separation of the alimentary and biliopancreatic limbs, different from the simple gastrojejunostomy shown.

questions.text: All are valid indications for surgery in asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age >60 years

 

  • Surgery is indicated in asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism if there is end-organ involvement or high-risk biochemical abnormalities.
  • Vertebral fractures indicate skeletal involvement → surgical indication.
  • Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above ULN increases risk of complications → surgical indication.
  • High 24-hour urine calcium (>400 mg/day) may indicate risk of nephrolithiasis → surgical indication.
  • Age >60 years alone is not a standalone indication; management can be conservative in elderly asymptomatic patients.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vertebral fracture: Correct indication. reflects skeletal involvement from hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above ULN: Correct indication. risk of nephrolithiasis and other complications.

 

Option D. 24-hour urine calcium >400 mg/day: Correct indication. increased risk of kidney stones or nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text: Identify the type of suture material given in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Monofilament

 

The suture material shown in the image is polydioxanone (PDS), which is a synthetic, absorbable, monofilament suture known for its strength and minimal tissue reactivity.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Braided: Refers to sutures composed of multiple intertwined filaments, which this is not.


Option C. Biological: Made from natural sources such as catgut, not synthetic like polydioxanone.


Option D. Polyfilament: Made from multiple filaments; polydioxanone is single-strand.

choices.text: Take consent from patient and re-explore

questions.text: A wide mouth non-indurated Meckel's diverticulum is found during surgery for acute appendicitis. What should be done?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nothing to be done 

 

  • Incidentally discovered Meckel’s diverticulum with a wide neck, non-indurated, and asymptomatic generally does not require resection.
  • Surgical excision is reserved for symptomatic, inflamed, or narrow-necked diverticula.
  • Removing an asymptomatic diverticulum can increase operative risk unnecessarily.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excision: Incorrect. unnecessary for asymptomatic, wide-necked diverticula.

 

Option B. Resection-anastomosis: Incorrect. reserved for complicated or narrow-necked diverticula.

 

Option D. Take consent and re-explore: Incorrect. intraoperative decision does not require additional consent for asymptomatic diverticulum.

choices.text: Rise in serum creatinine of >15% baseline
Rise in serum creatinine of >10% baseline
Rise in serum creatinine of >10 umol/l
Rise in serum creatinine of >15 umol/l

questions.text: The criteria for early renal graft dysfunction includes:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rise in serum creatinine of >10% baseline

 

  • Early graft dysfunction is defined by a rise in serum creatinine >10% from baseline in the immediate post-transplant period.
  • It reflects impaired graft function and may require further evaluation for rejection, obstruction, or vascular compromise.
  • Absolute creatinine changes (μmol/L) are less reliable than percentage change from baseline in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rise in serum creatinine of >15% baseline: Incorrect. too high a threshold, may delay diagnosis of early dysfunction.

 

Option C. Rise in serum creatinine of >10 μmol/L: Incorrect. absolute value insufficient, does not account for baseline.

 

Option D. Rise in serum creatinine of >15 μmol/L: Incorrect. same as above, percentage change is standard.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with a lump in her left breast for 2 years. On examination, a 6 x 4 cm mass is palpated. Dimpling of the skin and bloody discharge from the nipple is present. The lesion is invading the pectoralis major muscle. Ipsilateral Level I and Level II matted axillary lymph nodes and contralateral Level 1 axillary nodes are present. There was no distant metastasis. What is the TNM staging?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) T3N2M1

 

  • T3: Tumor >5 cm but ≤10 cm (6×4 cm).
  • N2: Ipsilateral axillary nodes clinically fixed or matted; contralateral node involvement increases N category.
  • M1: Presence of contralateral axillary node involvement is considered distant metastasis.
  • TNM staging guides treatment planning, prognosis, and adjuvant therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T4bN1M0: Incorrect. T4b requires ulceration or skin involvement, not just dimpling.

 

Option B. T3N2M0: Incorrect. contralateral nodal involvement → M1, not M0.

 

Option C. T4aN1M0: Incorrect. T4a = chest wall invasion; only skin dimpling present here.
